title: Slight inaccuracy in _.isPlainObject docs.
body:
The documentation for `_.isPlainObject` states:

> Checks if value is an object created by the Object constructor.

However, that doesn't appear to be entirely accurate as shown here:

``` javascript
_.isPlainObject(Object.create(null));
// => true
```

This result makes intuitive sense to me, but is not what the documentation seems to imply.

title: Add `_.iife` for immediately invoking functions.
body:
`_.iife` takes a function as its first argument and calls it immediately,
passing in any additional specified arguments to the function, and then returns
the value of whatever was returned from the called function. This is useful as a
semantic wrapper for IIFE's and/or mocking out asynchronous task-based functions
in tests, such as `setTimeout`.
#### Some background

On the Refinery29 mobile web team we like to stub out `setTimeout` in some of our tests and simply have it call the function given to it. We find that this reduces test complexity when the code under question is not dependent on that asynchronous behavior, and it also speeds up our suite by quite a lot. The way we usually go about this is by doing something like 

``` javascript
spyOn(window, 'setTimeout').and.callFake(function(fn) { fn(); });
```

But this looks ugly and get cumbersome to type. We wanted to be able to pass in a higher-order function that could be used as a default "call whatever your first argument is if it's callable" behavior (in the same way that `_.identity` provides a convenient iterator), and couldn't find a library function in lodash that did this. So rather than write it ourselves and have it never see the light of day, I thought that it could be a useful addition to lodash's utility function.

``` javascript
spyOn(window, 'setTimeout').and.callFake(_.iife);
```

Beyond just providing the utility described above, `_.iife` could also possibly be used in the classic IIFE way

``` javascript
_.iife(function(global) {
  // your module here
}, this);
```

To provide a more semantic indication of an IIFE than just `(function() { ... })();` which - while canonical - could stand to be more denotative of what it's actually doing. This is why I made the function be able to accept arguments.

Thank you very much for creating and maintaining lodash! It's an awesome library that we all love using.

``` js
_.where([null], { id: '1' })
// => TypeError: Cannot read property 'id' of null
```

Is this right? Why?

title: Add a 'toJSON()' for unwrapping the chained result
body:
Hello,

Does it make sense to add a 'toJSON' method that returns the chained wrapped value (same as 'value()' method)?

This is useful in nodejs use of lodash. Invoking 'value()' everytime an object needs to be exposed for serialization pollutes the code.

Cheers

title: Chaining _.remove() uses removed values to continue chain?
body:
_([1,2,3,NaN]).remove(isNaN).value();

> [NaN]

Although this behavior is consistent with the chaining continuing using the returned value of the last function in the chain, it does make the remove less useful easily used in the chain. Of course, one can cache the chain in the middle in order actually use remove, but that is definitely less desirable.

I'm curious as to what the maintainers opinions are on this matter.

title: _.isRegExp fails on Android <= 2.3
body:
Hey guys,

first issue I find in lodash, you seriously do a great job :o)

My issue is really specific: I work on mobile, and for a laaaarge compatibility, and I have to support the older versions of Android.
Today I ran over this issue: on this platform version, `typeof /./` returns `function`, and not `object` as it should, so `_.isRegExp` returns `false`. Mozilla had the same bug 14 years ago (https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=61911, interesting topic btw), and it seems that old Android native browser has some of these tricky holes.

Question: is `typeof value == 'object'` mandatory for `_.isRegExp`? Why did not `toString.call(value) == regexpClass` only do the job?

Thanks a lot for your thoughts guys

Thomas

title: Lo-Dash Underscore build issues: noconflict & each
body:
I was updating a [jsPerf](http://jsperf.com/foreach-test-test/3) to add Lo-Dash, & found 2 issues:

`var lodash = _.noConflict();` for the `lodash.backbone.min.js` caused an error.  I removed it, since for a later edit I wanted to add the main `lodash.min.js` anyway.

There is a huge perf difference between Lo-Dash's main & Backbone/Underscore build. (I was seeing if I should replace Underscore there.).  Perhaps you mimicked an old Underscore routine, which has since been updated?

title: Marginal utility of per-function packages
body:
Apologies if this is already on the roadmap, but when I tried to use an a la carte package, I noticed this:

```
ae@ae:~/projects/test
$ time npm install --silent lodash.merge --save
lodash.merge@2.4.1 node_modules/lodash.merge
├── lodash._slice@2.4.1
├── lodash._getarray@2.4.1 (lodash._arraypool@2.4.1)
├── lodash.isobject@2.4.1 (lodash._objecttypes@2.4.1)
├── lodash._releasearray@2.4.1 (lodash._maxpoolsize@2.4.1, lodash._arraypool@2.4.1)
├── lodash._basemerge@2.4.1 (lodash.foreach@2.4.1, lodash.isarray@2.4.1, lodash.forown@2.4.1, lodash.isplainobject@2.4.1)
└── lodash._basecreatecallback@2.4.1 (lodash.identity@2.4.1, lodash._setbinddata@2.4.1, lodash.support@2.4.1, lodash.bind@2.4.1)

real    0m4.329s
user    0m1.094s
sys 0m0.715s


ae@ae:~/projects/test
$ du -sh node_modules/lodash.merge/
920K  node_modules/lodash.merge/

ae@ae:~/projects/test
$ time npm install --silent lodash --save
lodash@2.4.1 node_modules/lodash

real    0m1.180s
user    0m0.367s
sys 0m0.422s


ae@ae:~/projects/test
$ du -sh node_modules/lodash
984K  node_modules/lodash
```

Using a standalone method is 4 times slower to install, and takes up almost the same amount of space in node-modules.  The number of dependencies seems a bit ridiculous.  If you were browserifying and targeting the browser, using a single method is about one fourth the size of the entire library:

```
$ ls -lh *.js
-rw-r--r-- 1 ae ae 226K Apr  1 19:59 all.browserify.js
-rw-r--r-- 1 ae ae   18 Apr  1 19:58 all.js
-rw-r--r-- 1 ae ae  55K Apr  1 20:08 all.uglify.js
-rw-r--r-- 1 ae ae  48K Apr  1 19:59 merge.browserify.js
-rw-r--r-- 1 ae ae   24 Apr  1 19:58 merge.js
-rw-r--r-- 1 ae ae  17K Apr  1 20:08 merge.uglify.js

```

(`all.js` and `merge.js` just `require("lodash")` and `require("lodash.merge)"`)

Since they all update in lock-step with the main library version, do the per-method packages need to do any dependency management at all?  Couldn't they just inline all their dependencies?  The one benefit I see to dependency management is that if you were using many lodash functions, the internal dependencies would be shared among them, amortizing some of the cost.  Otherwise, it seems like needless time and complexity added to npm install.

title: Add _.accept as an alias of _.filter
body: _.reject works in just the opposite way _.filter works. Intuition suggests that _.accept should exist too.

title: Add "_.zipObjects(key, values...)" (plural)
body:
I've noticed a common pattern in a lot of code (and in the code samples in the documentation if I'm not mistaken) when multiple objects of the same structure are created.

Ex. 

``` js
// Make a bunch of players
var players = [
    { name: "James", age: 21, score: 100 },
    { name: "Erica", age: 18, score: 110 },
    { name: "Eric", age: 24, score: 86},
    { name: "Melissa", age: 45, score: 72},
];
```

Currently, `_.zipObject` will only zip together one object but it would be really handy in these cases if you could do this:

``` js
// Ex. _.zipObjects(key, values...)
var players = _.zipObjects(
    [ "name", "age", "score" ], // First parameter is an array of keys, just like _.zipObject
    [ "James", 21, 100 ], // Second param an on are the values
    [ "Erica", 18, 110 ],
    [ "James", 24, 86 ],
    [ "Melissa", 45, 72 ]
);
```

This statement would be equivalent to the first example, and provides an easy sort hand way to create multiple objects without repetition or risk of a typo (as well as other use cases I haven't thought of, I'm sure)

I'd be willing to write all the code for this as well as unit tests and all that, let me know if you think this is a good idea or if you think the same should be changed, etc.

If and when I get the green light I'll fork this project and write the code to match the style of the rest of the code base.

Thanks for your time

title: Deep lodash module dependencies on Windows hit path length limit
body:
It looks like lodash is using npm to manage its internal dependencies. As a result it creates some pretty deep `node_modules` directory trees and runs up against the limit of 260 characters on Windows paths. Here's what it looks like on my system, [JSCS just wants to pull in _.assign](https://github.com/gustavohenke/grunt-jscs-checker/blob/master/tasks/lib/jscs.js#L83) and ends up with this 268-char path at the point where it dies:

```
C:\wamp\www\jquery-release\__release\repo\node_modules\grunt-jscs-checker\node_modules\lodash.assign\node_modules\lodash._basecreatecallback\node_modules\lodash.bind\node_modules\lodash._createwrapper\node_modules\lodash._basecreatewrapper\node_modules\lodash.isobject
```

There's a way to get around the path limit by prefixing the path name but I assume nothing on node or npm does this: http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/desktop/aa365247(v=vs.85).aspx#maxpath

title: Foreach according to docs, does not work.
body:
```
_.forEach({ one: 'two', two: 'three', four: 'five' }, function () { console.log(arguments) });
```

Throws `array.forEach is not a function`

You can do `_({ ... }).forEach(function () { ... });` and it will work however.

title: Question on dropping support for the legacy & mobile builds of Lo-Dash in version 3.0.0
body:
Do you plan to drop support for legacy environments with v3.0.0, or will support remain in place, just in a different manner?
## 

I'm currently using Lo-Dash in three JavaScript packages:

I serve the legacy version of Lo-Dash to IE8 in client JavaScript.

I also use the legacy version in server-based JavaScript that runs in an ancient Microsoft .Net Script Control (some flavor of ECMA-262, edition 3).

I serve the modern version of Lo-Dash in client JavaScript to all other browsers.
## 

I love that I can use Lo-Dash in those environments with a consistent API.

My concern is with the version of Lo-Dash I use in that old .Net Script Control. For reasons beyond my control, the control itself cannot be updated.

I really love the updates you're planning for the v3.0.0 API, but I am extremely wary of needing different Lo-Dash APIs in server and client code.

title: .clone should be chainable
body:
It would be nice if _(o).clone() returned a wrapped object to enable this kind of use:

```
var params = _(requestParams)
  .clone()
  .assign(userParams)
  .assign({
    Version: api.version,
    Format: 'JSON',
    Request: requestName
  })
  .value();
```

Is there a reason why this is not a supported behaviour? Perhaps having two functions would work...

cloneChain or cloneValue?

```
_.isDate("03/29/1977 03:30 pm") // true
```

title: The chaining behavior of `.at` is not documented
body: The `.at` function is not listed in http://lodash.com/docs#_.

title: A syntax to provide more control over chaining
body:
I tend to use the `_(...)` syntax when it makes my code easier to understand. This is usually a grammatical matter, e.g., `_(collection).sortBy('key')` is nicer than `_.sortBy(collection, 'key')`. But more often than not, I don't want to continue chaining, so I am forced to append `.value()`.

In another instance (though this situation is more rare), I had the opposite problem. I wanted to do something like `_(str).parseInt().range().each(...)`, but `parseInt()` doesn't chain.

The line drawn by lodash between chainable and non-chainable wrapper functions is somewhat arbitrary in places (though I understand the general rule). This problem will only increase as more features are included (such as string methods in v3). In any case, it seems to me that the user should have more control over chaining.

I'm not sure what would be the best way to accomplish this, but I'm thinking about a syntax like:

`_(str)._.parseInt()._.range().each(...);`

or perhaps:

`_(str).parseInt().range()._.each(...);`

With both, the choice of whether or not a method wraps its return value is fully determined by the presence or absence of a preceding `._.` in the chain.

I don't care about the exact syntax (I realize either of the above would break backwards compatibility), but it should be small and unobtrusive, and give the user full control on a case-by-case basis.

title: Extending Lodash to Support Different Collection Types
body:
I understand you might not want to add XPath support to lodash, but I was wondering if you could point me in the right direction so that I could extend it myself.

An XPathResult can be an iterator.  There is no length property; you have to just walk the collection via `iterateNext()` until you get null.  Is there any hook into lodash where I could add support for this kind of collection?  While this question is specific to XPath, the answer should help others adding support for different collection types.

title: docs format poorly after load
body:
running chrome (production), full screen on an 11' macbook air

![screenshot](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/27563/2236013/3084a3e2-9b53-11e3-9bcb-66b1b98a480b.gif)

title: ` _ is not defined` when using template in nodejs
body:
```
_.VERSION
"2.4.1"
```

Code is pretty simple. Expecting `s` to equal `hello mustache` (straight from the docs). 

```
ld = require('lodash')
ld.templateSettings = interpolate: /{{([\s\S]+?)}}/g
s = "" 
s = ld.template('hello {{ name }}!', { 'name': 'mustache' })
```

Result: 

```
ReferenceError: _ is not defined
  at eval (<anonymous>:4:26)
  at Function.template (/[dir]/node_modules/lodash/dist/lodash.js:6311:16)
```

Do I have to pass _ in in the options object? That seems really strange. Looks like this has come up before: https://github.com/lodash/lodash/issues/183 

The failing code looks like: 

`var __t, __p = '', __e = _.escape;  // _ is undefined`

I managed to get it working by changing 

```
     var sourceURL = '\n/*\n//# sourceURL=' + (options.sourceURL || '/lodash/template/source[' + (templateCounter++) + ']') + '\n*/';
      try {
        var result = Function(importsKeys, 'return ' + source + sourceURL).apply(undefined, importsValues);
```

to: 

```
     var sourceURL = '\n/*\n//# sourceURL=' + (options.sourceURL || '/lodash/template/source[' + (templateCounter++) + ']') + '\n*/';
      importsKeys.push("_");
      importsValues.push(_);
      try {
        var result = Function(importsKeys, 'return ' + source + sourceURL).apply(undefined, importsValues);
```

Still, this seems odd enough that I want to ask if I'm doing something wrong before submitting a PR. Maybe this is a problem in this line: 

```
      var imports = defaults({}, options.imports, settings.imports),
          importsKeys = keys(imports),
          importsValues = values(imports);
```

It's also worth noting that I didn't have any problem using template in coffeescript REPL.

title: `_.isEmpty` return `false` for non-falsey number values

``` js
_.isEmpty(123); // true
_.isEmpty('123'); // false
```

title: Add _.flip
body:
I find I often need to change the order of args of a function. ie, `f(a,b) -> f(b,a)`

The [flip function](https://github.com/rhysbrettbowen/Underscore.Extras#flipfunction-number) makes certain higher order [function practices easier](http://www.reddit.com/r/javascript/comments/1l9gqu/hey_underscorejs_youre_doing_functional/)

Some other functional combinators could be worth considering from [underscore-contrib](http://documentcloud.github.io/underscore-contrib/#function.combinators).

title: Fast multicolumn sort function
New API proposal: _.pluckMany
New API proposal: _.separate
body:
Hi!

I'm really struggling without such a function that acts like `Array#join()` but accepts any objects as separator and produces an array as output.

Some examples:

``` js
_.separate([1, 2, 3], 66) 
// → [1, 66, 2, 66, 3]

_.separate([{ text: 'John' }, { text: 'Blaine' }, { text: 'Mathias' }], { text: '·' }) 
// → [{ text: 'John' }, { text: '·' }, { text: 'Blaine' }, { text: '·' }, { text: 'Mathias' }]
```

Method name to be discussed.

Tell me what do you think about it. I can issue a PR if you okay with this proposition.

Thanks

title: New utility function proposal: _.not
AMD and Underscore.js Compatibility Builds
body:
Hey guys,

Underscore now registers itself as the named AMD module, `underscore`: (https://github.com/jashkenas/underscore/blob/master/underscore.js#L1340)

With the Backbone `v1.1.1` release, Backbone provides AMD support and expects  `underscore` and `jquery` dependencies: https://github.com/jashkenas/backbone/blob/master/backbone.js#L12

Lodash provides AMD support by registering as an anonymous AMD module: https://github.com/lodash/lodash/blob/master/lodash.js#L7726

Would it be possible to register as the named AMD module, `underscore`, for Underscore Compatibility Builds?

This would allow many Backbone projects to "just work" with Lodash without changing any Require.js configurations.  Thanks!

There is virtually nothing to describe to newer users what is meant by `The "interpolate" delimiter` or `The "escape" delimiter`. They'd have to go hunting on google, or indeed, go to underscore's API docs to know about these features or how templating works in general.

title: Ampersands are parsed incorrectly on API docs page

Ampersand signs are parsed parsed in a wrong way, therefore everywhere in the documentation they're written down as `&`.

For example in `_.isEqual` section it looks like this:

```
      aGreet = _.isString(a) && reGreet.test(a),
      bGreet = _.isString(b) && reGreet.test(b);
```

I'm not sure whether it's an issue with Docdown or documentation markup.

title: Add "browser" field for Browserify
body:
Browserify and other CJS builders will look for a "browser" field to use as an alternate "main" when targeting the browser environment.

https://github.com/substack/node-browserify#packagejson

Pointing it to the compat build would prevent issues like #288 happening out of the box, without any extra configuration.

title: Add `_.groupsOf`
body:
Hello,

What do you think about the following addition?

_.grouped(collection, size)

with the following behavior: 

```
var letters = ['a', 'b', 'c', 'd', 'e,' 'f', 'g', 'h', 'i', 'j', 'k'];
var grouped = _.grouped(letters, 3); // [['a', 'b', 'c'], ['d', 'e,' 'f'], ['g', 'h', 'i'], ['j', 'k']]

```

I find myself needing this quite often.

Cheers

title: use .apply for initial function call in compose then use .call in loop
body:
As discussed in issue #463 and http://jsperf.com/compose-each/4 (simple compose impl) a big performance win can be had by using .apply only on the first function call and using .call in the loop. This maintains the current behavior of passing all the arguments into the first function call but passing the returned values into subsequent functions.

Additionally, there isn't a reason to do any of this logic if a single function is passed in so just return that function if length === 1.

title: Don't use array iteration for small function composition
body:
http://jsperf.com/compose-each/4

I have been playing with compose and looking at its performance across browsers and I have noticed that it is dramatically slower than hand composing functions. So I realized that compose could look at the length of arguments and return a optimized version for specific argument lengths. When you do this you can match the speed hand composed functions.

Take a look the the jsperf. Would you be willing to consider a pull request that returned a 1arg, 2arg, 3arg, 4arg, 5arg falling back to the current behavior after that. 5 is arbitrary can be any number you feel good about.

An alternative slightly smaller but still significant speed improvement is only use .apply on the first function passing in arguments and in the loop use .call. 

Unless I am misunderstanding something you only need apply for the first function call because of variable arguments on entry but all future function calls use the return of the previous call so you can use call with no side effects and going from ~200k ops/sec to 1-2mil ops/sec (on my macbook pro safari). Small change for a big performance win. You can see that in the jsperf under simple compose impl.

body:

title: Lodash find/findIndex will not respect undefined while traversing
Method for array to "set"
Question concerning the underscore build & browser compatibility
body:
First off, thanks for @jdalton et al's work on lodash! Awesome stuff. I'm using the underscore build (2.4.1 based on underscore 1.5.2) and I need to support IE8. I notice the built source is using `for (var in iterable)` which is causing an unexpected error in IE8 (`Member not found`). I am under the impression that using `for ... in` without the `hasOwnProperty` check is to be avoided in IE <= 8. `lodash-cli` doesn't allow combining the `underscore` and `compat` modifiers, so are older browsers simply not supported with the underscore build?
###### Additional info: - Using Backbone 1.0.0

title: Test freeGlobal.self for browserified web workers.
body: `self` is the global context name in web workers. So `freeGlobal.self === freeGlobal` is `true` in that environment when lodash is packaged in a library/site for use in web workers.

title: isPlainObject rely on native Object.getPrototypeOf with no fallback
body:
If your platform doesn't provide `Object.getProtoypeOf`, then the logic used to assign to `getPrototypeOf` will assign `false` to it, and nobody provides a fallback, and `isPlainObject` doesn't check and just calls `getPrototypeOf` as a function, and this breaks `isPlainObject`.

A similar issue was noted (actually as a PR with fix, not as an issue) in #251, but was closed because it was assumed to be restricted to IE8. But this is actually a real problem in 2.3.1 (and I don't see any relevant changes skimming the 2.4.1 code). I'm hitting it because I'm using lodash.js in Node alongside [harmony-reflect](https://github.com/tvcutsem/harmony-reflect), which patches `Object.getPrototypeOf` in a way that causes lodash's reNative.test to fail, so lodash calculates `getPrototypeOf` as `false`.

I don't know if you care about coexisting with harmony-reflect (if you do, the answer can't just be "require lodash before harmony-reflect", because some of the prototype-patching that harmony-reflect does is actually necessary to happen before lodash sees the prototypes -- Array.isArray and Date.toString, for example).

title: Update documentation for _.result
body: _.result now supports a default value.

title: Added default value to _.result
Added Object.get()
`_()` w/ object 41% slower than underscore
body:
Ran benchmark via lodash.com/benchmarks, platform is `Chrome 32.0.1700.77 on OS X 10.8.5`, one of the tests is 41% slower than underscore:

```
`_(...)` with an object:
lodash.min x 9,785,847 ops/sec ±1.88% (89 runs sampled)
underscore-min x 13,969,735 ops/sec ±3.16% (83 runs sampled)
underscore-min is 41% faster.
```

Considering how lodash seems consistently faster than underscore in the other tests, seems like there's a problem, perhaps a regression, for _() w/ object?
Have only just discovered lodash, so my apologies if I'm reporting something you're already aware of.

Documentation for _.wrap
allow overriding Date.now
body: This fixes sinon's useFakeTimers. See https://github.com/lodash/lodash/issues/304 .

title: Use of _.template with data having nested object
body:
Hello, I'm using the following template to fill a ``, with the custom "interpolate" delimiters {{...}} (regex: /{{([\s\S]+?)}}/g): ``` ``` The data used to process the template is as following : ``` javascript [{id:1, firstName: 'user1 FN', lastName: 'user1 LN', country: {id:69, code: 'FR', label: 'France'}}, {id:2, firstName: 'user2 FN', lastName: 'user2 LN', country: null}] ``` When the template is processed, the following exception is thrown : "Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read property 'label' of null ". Shouldn't it be avoided ? I saw the issue https://github.com/lodash/lodash/issues/51 which is similar, but it concerned the global variable. In my case, the variable is the data object property. Sebastien.
{{lastName}} {{firstName}} {{country.label}}

title: uniq, difference, and intersection broken for large arrays if installed as individual modules on npm
body:
If you use any of these three methods as separate modules on npm, i.e.

```
var uniq = require('lodash.uniq');
var diff = require('lodash.difference');
var intersection = require('lodash.intersection');
```

And you use them on large arrays, they give erroneous results. Here is a test script demonstrating it

``` js
var _ = require('lodash')
var uniq = require('lodash.uniq')
var difference = require('lodash.difference')
var intersection = require('lodash.intersection')
var arr = []

for (var i = 0; i < 76; i++){
  arr.push('hello')
}

console.log('# of elements', arr.length)
console.log('# of unique elements (_.uniq)', _.uniq(arr).length)
console.log('# of unique elements (uniq)', uniq(arr).length)
console.log('# of different elements (_.difference)', _.difference(arr, arr).length)
console.log('# of different elements (difference)', difference(arr, arr).length)
console.log('# of common elements (_.intersection)', _.intersection(arr, arr).length)
console.log('# of common elements (intersection)', intersection(arr, arr).length)
```

Lodash version `2.4.1` in all cases. The result was

```
# of elements 76
# of unique elements (_.uniq) 1
# of unique elements (uniq) 76
# of different elements (_.difference) 0
# of different elements (difference) 76
# of common elements (_.intersection) 1
# of common elements (intersection) 0
```

I have tracked down the root cause: `lodash._keyprefix` is broken down into it's own module, and as such, there can be multiple copies of it, which is exactly what happened.  For the `uniq` case, I traced the dep ancestry:
1. `lodash.uniq -> lodash._baseuniq -> lodash._createcache -> lodash._cachepush -> lodash._keyprefix`
2. `lodash.uniq -> lodash._baseuniq -> lodash._cacheindexof -> lodash._keyprefix`

The problem with _keyprefix is that it is meant to be/needs to be executed exactly once, as it generates a uniq identifier.

``` js
var keyPrefix = +new Date + '';
```

There being two separate keyPrefixs in different places is what is causing the functions to malfunction.

title: _.partial appears to change context, unexpectedly
body:
(working with MongooseJS)
So, say I call

```
_.partial(models.Character.findById, target)
```

target being the ID of the thing I'm searching for, mongoose throws

```
TypeError: Object #<Object> has no method 'findOne'
    at Object.findById (A:\projects\api.edengames.co\node_modules\mongoose\lib\model.js:981:15)
    at Object.bound [as target] (A:\projects\api.edengames.co\node_modules\lodash\dist\lodash.js:1318:23)
...
```

the contents of findById are a single line, calling `this.findOne(...)`. It appears to lose context somehow.

title: Weirdness with _.bind and Superagent callbacks
body:
I was trying to wrap my head around this one today, and I finally settled on the conclusion that it feels like a bug (or undocumented edge case). I'm creating a `_.bind`'d copy of a callback function that follows the standard `(err, res)` pattern. But using this function inside of a [Superagent](https://github.com/visionmedia/superagent) `end()` method, the null `err` value is shifted off and `res` shifts into `err`'s place, leaving `res` undefined.

I created a [gist](https://gist.github.com/smitelli/8324403) that demonstrates the behavior. I'm running node 0.10.24, lodash 2.4.1, and superagent 0.16.0. Replacing lodash with underscore fixes the problem, and so does replacing `lodash.bind(function () {})` with `(function () {}).bind()`.

https://gist.github.com/smitelli/8324403

title: partialRight not working as expected when invoked with extra parameters
body:
Looks like _.partialRight returns a function that doesn't handle properly any extra parameters it may receive. Instead, it is replacing the partially applied parameter with the extra parameter.

See this commit for two tests that expose this bug: https://github.com/holden-caulfield/lodash/commit/04c78d869eec8ef0b44de9ed48d3d99c174f8ef4

Of course, the meaningful case is the "map" one. Since map always send you an extra parameter with the index on the collection, that index will always superseed any argument that was partially applied before.

The other case is just a silly example with the most minimal case I could find that fails.

I'll be happy to open a pull request if you think the tests are any useful.

Thanks!

title: Provide object key/array index to _.cloneDeep callback
Add genie to docs
body:
I would love to contribute this myself, but I'm not certain where to start. Just point me in the right direction, and I'll submit a pull request referencing this ticket.

In an effort to make the lodash docs more navigable and enhance their usability, I would like to contribute by bringing in a 3rd party library and a directive I wrote. The library and the Angular module each have public repos on GitHub and are registered with bower so we could include them via bower.

The library I'm talking about is called [genie](http://www.github.com/kentcdodds/genie) and the associated Angular module is [ux-genie](http://www.github.com/kentcdodds/ux-genie) (see the demo [here](http://kent.doddsfamily.us)). I think this would be especially useful to super users. Let me know where I can put this stuff.

If you'd rather me not pull in angular for ux-genie (I completely understand it if you don't) then I can do it without. I've been wanting to make a jQuery plugin or a pure JS version anyway.

title: WiKi resources: newest first?
body: I assumed [newest addition first](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/wiki/Resources/), so returning visitors don't have to scroll down.  Please let me know if you prefer the reverse.

title: understanding omit with more than one object
body:
i believe my lack of js skills has finally caught up with me

given this

``` javascript
var chars = [
  { 'name': 'barney',  'age': 36 },
  { 'name': 'fred',    'age': 40 },
  { 'name': 'pebbles', 'age': 1 }
];

console.log(_.sortBy(chars,'age'));

console.log(_.omit(chars,'age'));
```

why does sortBy work great but omit doesn't?

``` javascript
[ { name: 'pebbles', age: 1 },
  { name: 'barney', age: 36 },
  { name: 'fred', age: 40 } ]
{ '0': { name: 'barney', age: 36 },
  '1': { name: 'fred', age: 40 },
  '2': { name: 'pebbles', age: 1 } }
```

yes, sortBy works on a collection and omit works on an object but isn't chars both?
